newsitem.title: NEPAL: Nepal king summons parliament for Dec 16 debate.
newsitem.headline: Nepal king summons parliament for Dec 16 debate.

text.p: Nepal's King Birendra has summoned a special session of parliament to take up a no-confidence motion against Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba's coalition government, state-owned radio said on Tuesday.
The palace issued a statement read on Radio Nepal saying the monarch had called the session for 1 p.m. (0715 GMT) on December 16.

On Sunday, 11 breakaway deputies of the Rastriya Prajatantra Party (RPP), holding a crucial balance of power in parliament, announced they were withdrawing support for Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba's 15-month-old coalition government.
Seven of 13 RPP ministers resigned from Deuba's 46-member government.

The three-party coalition has controlled 108 seats in the 205-seat lower house, where Deuba's Nepali Congress party has 86 lawmakers. RPP has 19 seats and Nepal Sadbhavana Party (NSP) has three members.

But the opposition United-Marxist-Leninist (UML) party, with 87 deputies, has joined the 11 breakaway RPP lawmakers and had asked King Birendra to convene a special parliamentary session to take up the motion against Deuba.
To topple Deuba's government, his opponent would need at least 103 votes in the 205-seat Lower House of parliament.
The communist and rebel RPP faction claimed they control at least 102 votes while Deuba's Nepali congress has 86 seats.
In March, six RPP ministers resigned from the government, but they quickly patched up their differences with the government in time for Deuba to survive a no-confidence motion.
